awd_titl_txt: RUI: Development of Fast Scalable Adaptive High Order Methods for Solving the Boltzmann Equation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project's goal is to advance one's ability to use computer simulations to address scientific and technological challenges by employing modeling at microscopic scales using the kinetic Boltzmann equation. Applications of this proposal span the dynamics of gas, plasma, self-organizing systems, networks, and bacterial dynamics. The project will focus on a bottleneck issue in kinetic modeling --- the development of fast methods for high fidelity simulations of particle interactions in rarefied gases. The project's most immediate impact is in the development of novel aerospace technologies and in important U.S. initiatives in the development of clean energy, biotechnology, and new materials. This will be through its applications to computer simulation of devices that either operate in rarefied gas or are manufactured in vacuum. The project will provide training for the STEM workforce by engaging students in research. 
 
Despite of being studied intensely in the last decades, deterministic numerical solutions of the Boltzmann equation continue to be evasive. To achieve a full three-dimensional solution suitable for use in applications, fast scalable adaptive numerical approaches for evaluating the five-fold Boltzmann collision integral need to be devised. This proposal will address these shortcomings by developing convolution formulations of the Boltzmann collision integral based on nodal discontinuous Galerkin (nodal-DG) discretizations in the velocity variable, by developing adaptable nodal-DG wavelet discretizations of the collision operator on octree meshes, and by developing fast algorithms for evaluating the convolution form of the collision integral based on an application of the Fourier transform. The new methods will require at most O(n^6) operations for a fully deterministic evaluation of the Boltzmann collision integral, and will require O(n^5) memory units to store the pre-computed collision kernels, where n is the number of discretization points in one dimension in the velocity space. The new methods will be implemented on parallel architectures and will be scalable. Implementation of this proposal will result in the development of capabilities for producing high-fidelity solutions to the Boltzmann equation, capabilities for producing benchmark solutions and methods for validation of kinetic models. The research activities will result in a new application of nodal-DG wavelets to the approximation of the Boltzmann collision integral.

por.por_cntn:
Central to gas dynamics, the Boltzmann equation has the capacity to describe gas flows in regimes from continuum to rarefied. Its descriptive power is derived from the microscopic probabilistic representation of gas by a space and time dependent velocity distribution function of a large collection of particles. The Boltzmann equation finds a prominent use in problems arising in design of hypersonic air breathing engines and rocket thrusters, study of flows of particles into a vacuum, slow gas flows in micro devices, in plasmas and electron and photon transports. Emerging applications of the Boltzmann equation include self-organizing systems and flocking, as well as networks and bacterial dynamics. 

Intellectual Merit. The project resulted in several advancements toward the development of fast, scalable, and adaptive methods for numerical solution of the kinetic Boltzmann equation. The first advancement is the development of O(N2) approach to evaluate the Boltzmann collision operator based on nodal discontinuous Galerkin (DG) discretization in the velocity space and convolution formulation of the DG projection of the collision operator.  A major progress is achieved toward the development of adaptive discretizations of the Boltzmann collision operator based on the nodal-DG discretization using DG multiple wavelets. A multi-wavelet formulation for octrees is proposed, implemented, and tested. The second major advancement is the development of a reduced order model (ROM) for the Boltzmann equation based on a study of a class of solutions. Compared to O(N2) nodal-DG approach, the use of ROM results in 103 fold acceleration in the evaluation of Boltzmann collision operator, reducing the CPU time from minutes to fractions of a second. Additional advancements are the development of kinetic models with velocity-dependent collision frequency; development of kinetic models with adjustable equilibrium distribution, and the development of ultra-sparse approximations of kinetic equations using sums of Gaussian densities. Lastly, investigations were conducted to find low rank approximations for the collision operator based on semi-structured hierarchical decomposition of the collision kernel, singular value decomposition of the kernel, and, most recently, artificial neural networks approximations. Developed approaches were implemented in Fortran using OpenMP and MPI parallelizations and in Python. The developed software is available for download at https://github.com/alexmalekseenko.

Broader Impact. It is anticipated that the new methods will help advance our understanding of flows of non-continuum gas by providing high-fidelity benchmark solutions and by enabling efficient simulations of kinetic equations. The methods will enhance existing capabilities and will be applied to simulation of real gas effects in engineering applications, including design of space and high-altitude vehicles, miniatures devices, Knudsen pumps, and Knudsen propulsion systems. The software developed by the PI and the students has been adopted by three research groups in aerospace. The project provided training to three graduate students and five undergraduate students. Parallel research codes developed in this project and pubished case studies became an integral part of a graduate course in numerical solution of kinetic equations using high performance computing (HPC). The graduate course was offered twice since the beginning of the project and became a popular training ground for students seeking research opportunities and internships in computational mathematics.
